data.text: @jkbren Great work. Aside from the data errors, they are equating 'failure to reject the null hypothesis' with 'the null hypothesis is true', which is flawed to begin with.
@jkbren @GidMK Yes, it boggles the mind that a disease that is transmitted by contact from human to human would benefit from social distancing!
@sarabjustone @EuniceE62945638 @jkbren @SNMA @LmsaNational @NationalMedAssn @IndianCountry @nativenews_net The RepubliCons know, but they hide their real agenda.
@jkbren Were they really errors or were they intentional?  Schools couldn’t have opened if a 6ft distance between students were required.

@emilygraymd_mph @jkbren No, I agree. My point was just that the original paper was used to justify decreasing the distancing guidelines, when the guidelines were arbitrary to begin with, and decreasing them was clearly unjustified. Larger distances are better, masking is safer, stack the mitigations.

@jkbren Has the original paper been retracted yet?

Really excellent scholarship. Nice work!

@lagagne01 @jkbren Outdoors will be safer when there's a chance to go out & only in w (good) masks, idealy vent. Sure, it's aerosolized and will travel far over time. That's incorrectlty used to justify "no point in spacing." But space helps as allows dispersion, too. Layered mitigation
@sarabjustone @EuniceE62945638 @jkbren @SNMA @LmsaNational @NationalMedAssn @IndianCountry @nativenews_net Purposely infected them, like sacrificial lambs at the altar of capitalism.
@jkbren @gregggonsalves Yeah, always question “influential “ .  A warning bell right there.
